bioghist.p: Florence Bascom (1862-1945) was an educator and geological survey scientist who is considered to be the first American woman geologist. Bascom earned bachelor's and master's degrees at the University of Wisconsin, and in 1893, she became the first woman to receive a Ph.D. from Johns Hopkins University. Bascom taught at Ohio State University from 1893 to 1895 before joining the faculty of Bryn Mawr College, where she founded the geology department. Under her direction, the department gained a national reputation. In 1896 Bascom was named assistant geologist with the U.S. Geological Survey—the first woman ever to receive that appointment. Her work on the Mid-Atlantic Piedmont region led to the contributions for which she is best known—U.S. Geological Survey Folios on Philadelphia (1909), Trenton (1909), Elkton-Wilmington (1920), Quakertown-Doylestown (1931), and Honeybrook-Phoenixville (1938). Bascom also wrote some 40 scientific articles on genetic petrography, geomorphology, and gravels.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the professional papers of Florence Bascom. Materials include incoming and outgoing correspondence, largely related to Bascom's work with the U.S. Geological Survey; field notebooks, laboratory notes, maps, photographs, drawings; manuscripts and reprints; and correspondence between Dorothy Wyckoff and Howard Meyerhoff regarding the USGS scientific survey of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
